{{DISPLAYTITLE:Wendy Brown (political theorist)}} {{Infobox philosopher | name = Wendy Brown | image=WendyBrown2016.1.jpg | image_size= 220 | caption= Brown in Berkeley, 2016. | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1955|11|28}} | birth_place = | era = [[Contemporary philosophy]] | region = [[Western philosophy]] | school_tradition = {{hlist|[[Continental philosophy]] |[[Critical theory]] |[[Third-wave feminism]] |[[Queer theory]] |[[Postmodernism]] |[[Post-structuralism]] |[[Critical legal studies]]}} | main_interests = {{hlist|[[Democracy]] |[[Sovereignty]] |[[Citizenship]] |[[Rights]] |[[Gender]] |[[Identity (social science)|Identity]] |[[Power (social and political)|Power]] |[[Discourse]] |[[Liberalism]] |[[Neoliberalism]] |[[Toleration|Tolerance]] |[[Psychoanalysis]] |[[State (polity)|State]] |[[Law]] |[[Secularism]] |[[Critique]]}} | influences = {{hlist |[[Karl Marx]] |[[Michel Foucault]] |[[Sigmund Freud]] | |[[Friedrich Nietzsche]] |[[Frankfurt School]]| [[Sheldon Wolin]]<!--academic advisor-->}} | influenced = | notable_ideas = }} '''Wendy L. Brown''' (born November 28, 1955) is an American political theorist. She is Class of 1936 First Professor of [[Political Science]] and a core faculty member in The Program for [[Critical Theory]] at the [[University of California, Berkeley]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://polisci.berkeley.edu/people/faculty/person_detail.php?person=225|title=Wendy Brown - People in the Department|website=Polisci.berkeley.edu|accessdate=June 17, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://townsendlab.berkeley.edu/critical-theory/faculty|title=Faculty - Townsend Humanities Lab|website=Townsendlab.berkeley.edu|accessdate=June 17, 2012}}</ref>
==Career== Wendy Brown received her BA in both Economics and Politics from [[UC Santa Cruz]], and her M.A and Ph.D in [[political philosophy]] from [[Princeton University]]. Before she took a position at [[UC Berkeley]] in 1999, Brown taught at [[Williams College]] and [[UC Santa Cruz]]. At Berkeley, beyond her primary teaching roles in Political Theory and Critical Theory, Brown is also an affiliated faculty member of the Department of Rhetoric, the Jurisprudence and Social Policy Program, the Designated Emphasis in Women, Gender and Sexuality, and the Designated Emphasis in Early Modern Studies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rhetoric.berkeley.edu/people.php?page_id=1056&c=2|title=UCB Rhetoric - Affiliated Faculty|website=Rhetoric.berkeley.edu|accessdate=June 17, 2012}}</ref>
Brown lectures around the world and has held numerous visiting and honorary positions, including at the [[Institute for Advanced Study]] in Princeton, the [[Institute for Human Sciences]] in Vienna, the [[Goethe University Frankfurt|Goethe University]] in Frankfurt, the [[University of California Humanities Research Institute|UC Humanities Research Institute]] in Irvine, the Institute for the Humanities Critical Theory Summer School at [[Birkbeck, University of London]] (2012, 2015),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbk.ac.uk/bih/events/london-critical-theory-summer-school|title=London Critical Theory Summer School — The Birkbeck Institute for the Humanities, Birkbeck, University of London|website=Bbk.ac.uk|language=en-us|access-date=2017-07-19}}</ref> a Senior Invited Fellow of the Center for Humanities at [[Cornell University]] (2013), a Visiting Professor at [[Columbia University]] (2014), a [[Phi Beta Kappa]] Visiting Lecturer (2014),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbk.org/WEB/PBK_Member/PROGRAMS/Visiting_Scholars/2014-2015/Wendy_Brown.aspx|title=Phi Beta Kappa Visiting Lectures|website=Pbk.org|accessdate=2016-02-04}}</ref> a Visiting Professor of Law and Government at [[Cornell University]] (2015), the Shimizu Visiting Professor of Law at the [[London School of Economics]] (2015),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lse.ac.uk/genderInstitute/whosWho/profiles/visitingAcademics/pastVisitors.aspx |title=Previous Visitors to the Gender Institute at the LSE|website=Lse.ac.uk |accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref> and a Visiting Professor at the [[European Graduate School]] (2016).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://egs.edu/faculty/wendy-brown/lectures|title=Wendy Brown|accessdate=June 17, 2012}}</ref>
Among the honorary lectures Brown has delivered are the Beaverbrook Annual Lecture at McGill University (2015);<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mcgill.ca/ahcs/channels/event/2015-beaverbrook-annual-lecture-wendy-brown-neoliberalism-contra-democracy-ten-theses-255258|title=2015 Beaverbrook Annual Lecture{{!}} Wendy Brown {{!}} "Neoliberalism Contra Democracy: Ten Theses"|website=Art History & Communication Studies|language=en|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref> the Pembroke Center keynote at Brown University (2015);<ref>{{Citation|last=Brown University|title=Feminist Change and the University: Keynote Address by Wendy Brown (Video 3 of 3)|date=2015-03-18|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D2Eop1_T02s|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref> a keynote at the Zolberg Institute on Migration and Mobility (2016);<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://zolberginstitute.org/zimm-launch-event-mobility-in-post-democracy-with-keynote-address-by-wendy-brown-october-20th-6-30pm-the-auditorium-66-west-12th-street/|title=ZIMM launch event: "Mobility in Post-Democracy" keynote lecture by Wendy Brown, October 20th 6.30pm, The Auditorium, 66 West 12th Street. {{!}} Zolberg Institute on Migration and Mobility|date=2016-10-05|work=Zolberg Institute on Migration and Mobility|access-date=2018-07-30|language=en-US}}</ref> the fourth "Democracy Lecture" – following [[Thomas Piketty]], [[Naomi Klein]], and [[Paul Mason (journalist)|Paul Mason]] – in the Haus der Kulturen der Welt in Berlin (2017);<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hkw.de/de/programm/projekte/2015/democracy_lectures/democracy_lectures_start.php|title=Democracy Lectures|last=|first=|date=|website=Haus der Kulturen der Welt|language=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-29}}</ref> a plenary speech at the European Sociological Association conference in Athens (2017);<ref>{{cite web|url=http://esa13thconference.eu/|title=13th ESA Conference {{!}} Athens {{!}} 29.08 - 01.09.2017|website=13th Conference of the European Sociological Association|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-30}}</ref> the Wellek Lectures at UC Irvine (2018);<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.humanities.uci.edu/critical/events/past_wellek.php|title=Wellek Lecture Series {{!}} UCI Critical Theory|website=www.humanities.uci.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref> and the Gauss Lecture at Princeton University (2018).<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://humanities.princeton.edu/event/gauss-seminar-in-criticism/|title=Gauss Seminar in Criticism: Wendy Brown|work=Humanities Council|access-date=2018-07-30|language=en}}</ref>
Brown's work has been translated into more than twenty languages and has received many awards. Brown served as Council Member of the [[American Political Science Association]] (2007–09) and as Chair of the UC Humanities Research Institute Board of Governors (2009–11).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uchri.org/profiles/wendy-brown-3|title=Wendy Brown - UC Humanities Research InstituteUC Humanities Research Institute|website=Uchri.org|accessdate=2016-09-24}}</ref> In 2012, her book Walled States, Waning Sovereignty won the David Eastman Award.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.apsanet.org/MEMBERSHIP/Organized-Sections-by-Title/Organized-Section-Awards/Section-17 |title=David Eastman Award from the Foundations of Political Thought Section of the American Political Science Association|website=Apsanet.org|accessdate=June 5, 2017}}</ref> Brown received the 2016 Distinguished Teaching Award, UC Berkeley's most prestigious honor for teaching.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://teaching.berkeley.edu/programs/distinguished-teaching-award/2016-distinguished-teaching-award-recipients|title=UC Berkeley Distinguished Teaching Award to Wendy Brown|website=Teaching.berkeley.edu|accessdate=June 5, 2017}}</ref> She received a UC Presidents Humanities Research Fellowship (2017–18) and is currently a [[John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation|Guggenheim Fellow]] (2017–18).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.berkeley.edu/2017/04/07/guggenheim-fellows-2017|title=Gugenheim Awards|last=|first=|date=|website=News.berkeley.edu|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=June 5, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gf.org/fellows/all-fellows/wendy-brown|title=Current Guggenheim Fellow Wendy Brown|website=Gf.org|accessdate=June 5, 2017}}</ref>
Brown's thinking on the decline of sovereignty and the hollowing out of democracy has found popular and journalistic audiences, with discussions of her arguments appearing in ''[[The Guardian]]'' and ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]''{{'}} articles.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/jul/31/democracy-dying-people-worried-putin-erdogan-trump-world|title=Democracy is dying – and it's startling how few people are worried|last=Mason|first=Paul|date=2017-07-31|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-08-03|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/06/opinion/sunday/the-walls-in-our-heads.html|title=The Walls in Our Heads|last=Vanderbilt|first=Tom|date=2016-11-04|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-08-03|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Brown has appeared in documentary films including "The Value of the Humanities" (2014) and "What is Democracy?" (directed by [[Astra Taylor]], 2017).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thevalueofthehumanities.com/|title=The Value of the Humanities|last=ValueMedia|website=www.thevalueofthehumanities.com|language=en|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://blog.nfb.ca/blog/2017/05/29/what-is-democracy-astra-taylors-necessary-new-doc/|title=What is Democracy? Astra Taylor's Necessary New Doc - NFB/blog|date=2017-05-29|work=NFB/blog|access-date=2017-08-14|language=en-US}}</ref>
Together with [[Michel Feher]], Brown is co-editor of the Zone Books' series '''''Near Futures''''' and its digital supplement '''''Near Futures Online'''''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zonebooks.org/pdf/ZoneBooks2015.pdf|title=Near Futures, Series Announcement|publisher=Zone Books|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://mitpress.mit.edu/category/series/zone-near-futures|title=Near Futures, publications from Zone Books and MIT Press|website=Mitpress.mit.edu|accessdate=June 6, 2017}} {{cite web|url=http://www.nearfuturesonline.org|title=Near Futures Online Issue No. 1 (March 2016) “Europe at a Crossroads”|website=Nearfuturesonline.org|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref>
==Overview of work== Brown has established new paradigms in [[critical legal studies]] and [[feminist theory]].<ref>Wendy Brown, Christina Colegate, John Dalton, Timothy Rayner, Cate Thill, [http://sydney.edu.au/contretemps/6January2006/brown.pdf Learning to Love Again: An Interview with Wendy Brown], Contretemps 6, January 2006: 25-42</ref> She has produced a body of work drawing from [[Marx]]'s critique of capitalism and its relation to religion and secularism,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://quiparle.dukejournals.org/content/23/1.toc|title="Is Marx (Capital) Secular?" Qui Parle (2014) 23(1): 109-124.|last=Brown|first=Wendy|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.freie-radios.net/41387 |title=FRN: Is Marx (Capital) Secular? Vortrag von Wendy Brown vom Re-thinking Marx Kongress |website=Freie-radios.net |date= |accessdate=2017-07-26}}</ref> [[Nietzsche]]'s usefulness for thinking about power and the ruses of morality, [[Max Weber]] on the modern organization of power, [[Freudian psychoanalysis]] and its implications for political identification,<ref>R Gressgård. [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1080/08038740802441063 "Feminist Theorizes the Political: The Political Theory of Wendy Brown"], tandfonline.com; accessed February 1, 2017.</ref> [[Michel Foucault|Foucault]]'s work on governmentality and [[neoliberalism]], as well as other contemporary [[Continental philosophy|continental philosophers]].<ref name="springer1">{{cite journal|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10691-016-9314-z|title=Feminism, Law, and Neoliberalism: An Interview and Discussion with Wendy Brown|accessdate=June 6, 2017 | doi=10.1007/s10691-016-9314-z|volume=24|journal=Feminist Legal Studies|pages=69–89 | last1 = Cruz | first1 = Katie}}</ref><ref name="sociologicalimagination.org">{{cite web|url=http://sociologicalimagination.org/archives/17800|title=Author Meets Readers: Wendy Brown's Undoing the Demos|website=Sociologicalimagination.org|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref> Bringing these resources together with her own thinking on a range of topics, Brown's work aims to diagnose modern and contemporary formations of [[political power]], and to discern the threats to democracy entailed by such formations.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10691-016-9314-z |title=Feminism, Law, and Neoliberalism: An Interview and Discussion with Wendy Brown|accessdate=June 6, 2017 | doi=10.1007/s10691-016-9314-z|volume=24|journal=Feminist Legal Studies|pages=69–89 | last1 = Cruz | first1 = Katie}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://sociologicalimagination.org/archives/17800 |title=Author Meets Readers: Wendy Brown's Undoing the Demos|website=Sociologicalimagination.org |accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref>
===''States of Injury: Power and Freedom in Late Modernity'' (1995)=== In this work Brown asks how a sense of woundedness can become the basis for individual and collective forms of identity. From outlawing hate speech to banning pornography, Brown argues, well-intentioned attempts at protection can legitimize the state while harming subjects by codifying their identities as helpless or in need of continuous governmental regulation. While breaking ground in political theory, this work also represents one of Brown's key interventions in feminist and queer theory. The book offers a novel account of legal and political power as constitutive of norms of sexuality and gender. Through the concept of "wounded attachments", Brown contends that psychic injury may accompany and sustain racial, ethnic, and gender categories, particularly in relation to state law and discursive formations. In this and other works Brown has criticized representatives of second wave feminism, such as [[Catharine MacKinnon]], for reinscribing the category of "woman" as an essentialized identity premised on injury.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://acc.english.ucsb.edu/ACGCC%2014-15/Brown_The%20Impossibility%20of%20Women%27s%20Studies.pdf|title=The Impossibility of Women's Studies|website=acc.english.ucsb.edu|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://press.princeton.edu/titles/5715.html|title=States of Injury book description|website=Press.princeton.edu|accessdate=June 6, 2017}} Prior to ''States of Injury'', Brown addressed ''Toward a Feminist Theory of the State'' (1989) in ''[[The Nation]]'', characterizing it as a "profoundly static world view and undemocratic, perhaps even anti-democratic, political sensibility" as well as "flatly dated" and "developed at 'the dawn of feminism's second wave ... framed by a political-intellectual context that no longer exists -- a male Marxist monopoly on radical social discourse'". See Wendy Brown, "Consciousness Razing", ''[[The Nation]]'', January 8/15, 1990, pp. 61–64. for reinscribing the category of "woman" as an essentialized identity premised on injury.</ref>
=== ''Politics Out of History'' (2001) === This book comprises a series of essays on contemporary political issues from the problem of moralism in politics to the legacies of past injustices in the present. Throughout her thematically overlapping chapters, Brown asks: "What happens to left and liberal political orientations when faith in progress is broken, when both the sovereign individual and sovereign states seem tenuous, when desire seems as likely to seek punishment as freedom, when all political conviction is revealed as contingent and subjective?"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://press.princeton.edu/titles/7210.html|title=Politics Out of History|website=Princeton University Press|language=en|access-date=2017-11-20}}</ref> Much of this book takes history and liberalism themselves as objects of theoretical reflection and sites of contestation. Drawing on a range of thinkers, such as [[Sigmund Freud|Freud]], [[Karl Marx|Marx]], [[Friedrich Nietzsche|Nietzsche]], [[Baruch Spinoza|Spinoza]], [[Walter Benjamin|Benjamin]] and [[Jacques Derrida|Derrida]], Brown rethinks the disorientation and possibility inherent to contemporary democracy.
===''Edgework: Critical Essays on Knowledge and Politics'' (2005)=== This work consists of seven articles responding to particular occasions, each of which "mimic, in certain ways, the experience of the political realm: one is challenged to think here, now, about a problem that is set and framed by someone else, and to do so before a particular audience or in dialogue with others not of one's own choosing." Each individual essay begins with a specific problem: what is the relationship between love, loyalty, and dissent in contemporary American political life?; how did neoliberal rationality become a form of governmentality?; what are the main problems of women's studies programs?; and so on. According to Brown, the essays do not aim to definitively answer the given questions but "to critically interrogate the framing and naming practices, challenge the dogmas (including those of the Left and of feminism), and discern the constitutive powers shaping the problem at hand."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://press.princeton.edu/titles/8079.html|title=Wendy Brown, Edgework, Princeton University Press|website=Press.princeton.edu|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref>
===''Regulating Aversion: Tolerance in the Age of Identity and Empire'' (2006)=== In this book, Brown subverts the usual and widely accepted notion that [[Toleration|tolerance]] is one of the most remarkable achievements of Western modernity. She suggests that tolerance (or toleration) cannot be perceived as the complete opposite to violence. At times, it can also be used to justify violence. Brown argues that tolerance primarily operates as a discourse of subject construction and a mode of governmentality that addresses or confirms asymmetric relations between different groups, each of which must then "tolerate" other groups and categories or "be tolerated" by the dominant groups and categories.
To substantiate her thesis, Brown examines the tolerance discourse of figures like [[George W. Bush]], [[Jimmy Carter]], [[Samuel P. Huntington|Samuel Huntington]], [[Susan Okin]], [[Michael Ignatieff]], [[Bernard Lewis]], and [[Seyla Benhabib]] and argues that "tolerance as a political practice is always conferred by the dominant, it is always a certain expression of domination even as it offers protection or incorporation to the less powerful."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://press.princeton.edu/titles/8306.html|title=Regulating Aversion|website=Princeton University Press|access-date=2017-07-23}}</ref> Among those influenced by Brown's thinking on this subject are [[Joan Wallach Scott]] and [[Slavoj Žižek]],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Žižek|first=Slavoj|date=2008-04-01|title=Tolerance as an Ideological Category|url=http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/abs/10.1086/592539|journal=Critical Inquiry|volume=34|issue=4|pages=660–682|doi=10.1086/592539|issn=0093-1896}}</ref> whose respective works ''The Politics of the Veil'' (2007) and ''Violence: Six Sideways Reflections'' (2007) draw heavily on Brown's account of tolerance discourse.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YD74-yqAp-cC&pg=PR11&lpg=PR11&dq=joan+wallach+scott+politics+of+the+veil+wendy+brown&source=bl&ots=Gw58u1KuHR&sig=Llvq6iqdC19pO2Sls2_RMFnR8mE&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi1vMiMraDVAhWCxFQKHUP3A08Q6AEIVzAH#v=onepage&q=joan%20wallach%20scott%20politics%20of%20the%20veil%20wendy%20brown&f=false |title=The Politics of the Veil |author=Joan Wallach Scott |page=11 |website=Books.google.com |date=2010-08-22 |accessdate=2017-07-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar?bav=on.2,or.r_cp.&biw=1118&bih=618&um=1&ie=UTF-8&lr&cites=7277941321159015026 |title=Google Scholar |website=Scholar.google.com |date=2001-09-11 |accessdate=2017-07-26}}</ref>
In a debate with [[Rainer Forst]] at the ICI in Berlin Brown addressed this problematic again,<ref>[https://www.ici-berlin.org/videos/spannungsuebung-3/ The power of tolerance]'' – Debate between Wendy Brown and Rainer Forst, ICI Berlin, 2008] (July 16, 2015).</ref> later published as a co-authored book, The Power of Tolerance (2014). Here Brown argues against primarily moral or normative approaches to power and discourse, and warns against the dangers of uncritically celebrating the liberal ideal of tolerance, as frequently happens in Western notions of historical, civilizational or moral progress.<ref>[http://cup.columbia.edu/book/the-power-of-tolerance/9780231170185 ''The Power of Tolerance: A Debate''], Columbia.edu (July 16, 2015).</ref>
===''Les Habits neufs de la politique mondiale'' (2007)=== Published exclusively in French, ''Les habits neufs de la politique mondiale'' (''The New Clothes of World Politics'') argues that the following political fact is irreversible: liberal democracy, as a global social and historical modality of statecraft, is dying. The two movements delivering such blows, neoliberalism and neoconservatism, feature both resonances and disonances. Brown argues that whilst the former acts as a political rationality, a mode of general regulation of behavior, the latter is both necessary to its survival, and parasitic of its survival. As a form of governmentality that redefines freedom, neoliberalism will moralize politics, limiting its scope; this is the function of neo-conservatism.
===''Walled States, Waning Sovereignty'' (2010)=== This book examines the revival of wall-building under shifting conditions of global capitalism. Brown not only problematizes the assumed functions of walls, such as the prevention of crime, migration, smuggling, and so on. She also argues that walling has taken on new a significance due to its symbolic function in an increasingly globalized and precarious world of financial capital. As individual identity as well as nation-state sovereignty are threatened, walls become objects invested with individual and collective desire. Anxious efforts to shore up national identity are thus projected onto borders as well as new material structures that would appear to secure them.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zonebooks.org/titles/BROW_WAL.html |title=Zone Books, Wendy Brown's Walled States, Waning Sovereignty|website=Zonebooks.org |accessdate=June 6, 2017}} See also, Timothy Shenk, "[https://www.dissentmagazine.org/blog/booked-3-what-exactly-is-neoliberalism-wendy-brown-undoing-the-demos Booked #3: What Exactly Is Neoliberalism?]" Dissent Magazine</ref> The book was reprinted with a new preface by the author following the 2016 election of [[Donald Trump]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://zonebooks.org/pdf/ZoneBooks2017.pdf |format=PDF |title=Zone Books |date=2017 |website=Zonebooks.org |accessdate=2017-07-26}}</ref>
===''Undoing the Demos: Neoliberalism's Stealth Revolution'' (2015)=== Brown's study begins by engaging and revising key arguments in [[Michel Foucault]]'s ''The Birth of Biopolitics'' with the aim of analyzing different ways that democracy is being hollowed out by neoliberal rationality.<ref name="sociologicalimagination.org"/> She describes neoliberalism as a thoroughgoing attack on the most foundational ideas and practices of democracy. The individual chapters of the book examine the effects of neoliberalization on higher education, law,<ref name="springer1"/> governance,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.publicseminar.org/2015/08/on-wendy-brown/#.WTZ0JBN97wc|title=On Wendy Brown|website=Publicseminar.org|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref> the basic principles of liberal democratic institutions,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/european-journal-of-sociology-archives-europeennes-de-sociologie/article/undoing-the-undoing-of-the-demos-brown-wendy-undoing-the-demos-neoliberalisms-stealth-revolution-new-york-zone-books-2015/A50DF30DA9958B43CA3A795F7EEB0B66|title=Review of Wendy Brown: Undoing the Demos|website=Cambridge.org|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref> as well as radical democratic imaginaries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.popmatters.com/column/194010-neoliberalism-is-changing-our-world-without-our-even-noticing|title=Undoing the Demos Review in Pop Matters|website=Popmatters.com|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref>
Brown treats "neoliberalism as a governing rationality through which everything is 'economized' and in a very specific way: human beings become market actors and nothing but, every field of activity is seen as a market, and every entity (whether public or private, whether person, business, or state) is governed as a firm." To address such threats, Brown argues, democracy must be reinvigorated not only as an object of theoretical inquiry but also as a site of political struggle.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zonebooks.org/titles/BROW_UND.html |title=Zone Books, Wendy Brown: Undoing the Demos |website=Zonebooks.org|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref>
=== ''Neoliberalism's Frankenstein: Authoritarian Freedom, White Nationalism, and the Weaponization of Moral Values'' === Brown is currently researching right nationalism in the US, completing a book provisionally titled ''Neoliberalism's Frankenstein: Authoritarian Freedom, White Nationalism, and the Weaponization of Moral Values''. The book will shift between the frames of neoliberal governmentality, Nietzsche's social analysis and Marcuse's psychoanalysis to explain the production of a society unmoored from moral concerns (hence social justice), obligations to truth (the post-truth moment) and democratic interests (replaced by the self-interest of human capital). Brown draws from [[The Will to Power (manuscript)|The Will to Power]] by Nietzsche and Marcuse's [[One-Dimensional Man]], attributing these right energies to a combination of world-historical nihilism and forces of consumer culture in advance industrial society. Nihilism has, Brown argues, largely generated 'neoliberal reason itself, which posits no value apart from that generated by price and speculative markets.'<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brown|first=Wendy|date=2018|title=Neoliberalism's Frankenstein: Authoritarian Freedom in Twenty-First Century "Democracies"|url=https://ctjournal.org/index.php/criticaltimes/article/view/12|journal=Critical Times: Interventions in Global Critical Theory|language=en|volume=1|issue=1|page=71|pages=|via=}}</ref>
== Public life == [[File:Wendy Brown delivering the Democracy Lecture at the HKW Berlin in 2017. Photograph by Santiago Engelhardt.jpg|thumb|Wendy Brown giving the Democracy Lecture at the HKW Berlin in 2017. Photo by Santiago Engelhardt.]] A prominent public intellectual in the United States, Brown has written and spoken about issues of free speech,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ucbfa.org/2014/10/free-speech-is-not-for-feeling-safe-by-wendy-brown/|title=Free Speech is not for Feeling Safe, by Wendy Brown|website=Ucbfa.org|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref> public education, political protest,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ucbfa.org/2014/09/the-operation-of-the-machine/|title=Event on the Operation of the Machine|website=Ucbfa.org|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref> LGBTQ issues, sexual assault,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ucbfa.org/2016/03/statement-on-sexual-harassment-at-uc-berkeley|title=Feminist Statement on Sexual Harassment at UC Berkeley|website=Ucbfa.org|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref> Donald Trump,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://criticaltheory.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/Brown.The-End-of-the-World-as-We-Know-It.Artforum.December-2016.pdf|title=The End of the World as We Know It|last=Brown|first=Wendy|date=|website=Criticaltheory.berkeley.edu|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> conservatism, neoliberalism,<ref>{{Citation|last=New Economic Thinking|title=Wendy Brown: How Neoliberalism Threatens Democracy|date=2016-05-25|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZMMJ9HqzRcE|publisher=[[YouTube]]|accessdate=2017-07-25}}</ref> and other matters of national and international concern.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nearfuturesonline.org|title=Near Futures Online Issue No. 1 (March 2016) “Europe at a Crossroads” (Wendy Brown, consulting editor)|website=Nearfuturesonline.org|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref>
For decades, Brown has been active in efforts to resist measures toward the privatization of the [[University of California]] system.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/21528635|title=The Economist|website=Economist.com|accessdate=June 5, 2017}}</ref> In her capacity as co-chair of the Berkeley Faculty Association, she raised awareness, organized marches, and spoke publicly about the privatization of public education.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ucbfa.org/2011/09/talking-points-in-defense-of-uc-and-public-education|title=In Defense of UC and Public Education|website=Ucbfa.org|accessdate=June 17, 2012}}</ref> She has been critical of the university's decision to cut costs by utilizing lecturers rather than hiring tenure and tenure track professors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailycal.org/2011/07/07/academic-council-approves-recommendation-to-utilize-more-lecturers|title=The Daily Californian - Academic Council approves recommendation to utilize more lecturers|website=Dailycal.org|accessdate=June 17, 2012}}</ref> Relatedly, she has voiced concern over the perils of the UC's proposed online education programs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ucbfa.org/2010/10/wendy-brown-on-online-education|title=Wendy Brown on Online Education|date=2010-10-20|website=Ucbfa.org|accessdate=2016-09-24}}</ref><ref>For Brown's article on this topic, published in a "Qui Parle" special issue, see {{cite web|url=https://www.dukeupress.edu/qui-parle-20-1/?viewby=title|title=Wendy Brown article on Education in Qui Parle: Critical Humanities and Social Sciences|website=Dukeupress.edu|date=2010-10-20|accessdate=2016-09-24}}</ref>
Brown has criticized university administration for their response to sexual assault. "I think many faculty feel there are repeat harassers on our faculty who are never charged ... Graduate students gave up on careers, and these perpetrators were allowed to continue, and that was wrong—never should have happened," she said.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailycal.org/2016/03/28/feminist-uc-berkeley-faculty-members-call-for-improved-response-to-sex-harassment|title=Feminist UC Berkeley faculty members call for improved sexual harassment policy|website=Dailycal.org |accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref>
At the "99 Mile March" to Sacramento she addressed her criticism to more general trends: "We are marching to draw attention to the plight of public education in California and to implore Californians to re-invest in it. For all its resources, innovation and wealth, California has sunk to nearly the bottom of the nation in per student spending, and our public higher education system, once the envy of the world, is in real peril."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ucbfa.org/2012/02/uc-faculty-join-99-mile-march-to-sacramento|title=UC Faculty Join "99 Mile March" to Sacramento|website=Ucbfa.org|accessdate=June 17, 2012}}</ref> Brown supported [[Occupy Wall Street]] as part of the UC faculty council,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailycal.org/2011/10/16/uc-faculty-council-endorses-occupy-wall-street|title=UC faculty council endorses Occupy Wall Street | The Daily Californian|date=2011-10-16|website=Dailycal.org|accessdate=2016-09-24}}</ref> claiming that "We understand this to be part of what (the movement) stands for. We are delighted by the protests and consider our campaign to be at one with it."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/384018/summary|title=On the Demos, by Wendy Brown|website=Muse.jhu.edu|accessdate=June 5, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://muse.jhu.edu/article/459205|title=On Occupy|website=Muse.jhu.edu|accessdate=June 5, 2017}}</ref>
==Personal life== Brown is a native of [[California]] and lives in Berkeley with her wife [[Judith Butler]] and son.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/thecut/2016/06/judith-butler-c-v-r.html|title=It's Judith Butler's World - The Cut|website=Nymag.com|accessdate=2016-09-24}}</ref>

----'''Zacatepec Chatino''' is an [[Indigenous languages of Mesoamerica|indigenous Mesoamerican language]], one of the [[Chatino languages|Chatino]] family of the [[Oto-Manguean languages]]. It is often referred to as '' ChaqF tinyaJ KichenA tziC Chatino de San Marcos Zacatepec'' or ''Chatino de Zacatepec'' as it is distinct from other [[Chatino languages|Chatino]] languages in the region. Zacatepec Chatino is part of the Eastern Chatino languages. It is spoken in the town of San Marcos Zacatepec, a town of approximately 1,000 people and inhabited by an [[Indigenous peoples|indigenous group]] known as the [[Chatino people]]. The language was once spoken in the village of [[Juquila District|Juquila]], but is now virtually extinct with two surviving speakers in the area (Villard 2015).
Zacatepec Chatino is a highly endangered language as it is spoken by about 300 Chatino's whom are all above 50 years of age.
{{Infobox language |name=Zacatepec Chatino |altname=Chatino de San Marcos Zacatepec |nativename=Cha’ jna’a |states=[[Mexico]] |region=[[Oaxaca]], Southern Central Mexico |speakers=300 |date=2015 |ref=e18 |familycolor=American |fam1=[[Oto-Manguean]] |fam2=[[Zapotecan languages|Zapotecan]] |fam3=[[Chatino languages|Chatino]] |fam4=Zacatepec–Highlands |iso3=ctz |glotto=zaca1242 |glottoname=Zacatepec Chatino }}
==Classification== Chatino refers to three closely related languages; the three being Eastern Chatino, [[Tataltepec Chatino|Tataltepec]] Chatino, and [[Zenzontepec Chatino|Zenzontepec]] Chatino of the Zapotecan branch. Zacatepec Chatino falls under the Eastern Chatino branch.
Zacatepec Chatino, being part of Chatino language family, has shallow [[orthography]]. It is more conservative then its Chatino counterparts as it conserves the [[Penultimate rule|penultimate]] syllables of disyllabic roots.
==History== Little is known about the history of Zacatepec Chatino but according to Stéphanie Villard who studied and presented her thesis on the language, it has been on a decline for the past 40 years as natives continue to expand their ties with non-Chatino communities. With the help of the Zacatepec Chatino Documentation Project, Villard has uncovered some of the remnants of the language with the help of many natives from the area. The project includes visits in 2005 and 2006 by Hilaria Cruz, Emiliana Cruz, [[Megan Crowhurst]] as well as preliminary analysis of tones in H. Cruz y Woodbury in 2006. It also includes intensive work since 2006 by Stéphanie Villard, including 150 hours of audio, a sketch, papers on sandhi and inflection and grammar as well as short visits concentrating on textual documentation, tone, & morphology
The major language spoken in Zapotec Chatino and its surrounding regions is Spanish so it is no surprise that many foreigners are coming to San Marcos Zacatepec speaking Spanish and not Chatino.
Although Spanish is the [[official language]] in San Marcos Zacatepec, Oaxaca, many government officials communicate in Zacatepec Chatino. A study conducted by Villard revealed that majority of the younger population are monolingual Spanish speakers.
==Geographic distribution== Zacatepec Chatino is only spoken in San Marcos Zacatepec, Oaxaca in the [[Sierra Madre de Oaxaca|Sierra Madre]] region of Mexico.
===Dialects/Varieties===
Since Zacatepec Chatino is unintelligible with other Chatino varieties, it does not have any other dialects or varieties associated with it.
==Phonology==
=== Vowels === Villard (2015) reports that Zacatepec Chatino presents voicing of non-continuant after nasals, vowel harmony, and contrastive nasal vowels. It also lacks labial phonemes and has 4 levels of pitch ranging from low to high. It also presents 15 specific tonal sequences that can define 15 Lexical classes.
Its phonology presents a rich tonal system with a large inventory of phonemic tonal sequences as well as intricate [[sandhi]] patterns.
The vowels in Zacatepec Chatino are {{IPA|/i e a o u/}} and have several rules they have to follow which are juxtaposed with the nasal vowels among each other.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Villard|first=Stephanie|date=2015|title=The phonology and morphology of Zacatepec eastern Chatino|url=http://hdl.handle.net/2152/31492|journal=UT Electronic Theses and Dissertations|doi=|pmid=|access-date=May 3, 2016}}</ref>
/a/ does not present any restrictions in its distribution. /a/ is pronounced [a] and may be slightly nasalized. Here are some examples:
''n'''ǎ''' [na''] thing
''p'''a̋'''[pa''] dad
''kw'''ā ́'''[kwa]'' already
''mp'''aà''' ̋ [mba:''] godfather
''Wy'''àa̋['''bja:]'' Santos Reyes Nopala, Oaxaca
''ch'''ǎ'''ʔ [t͜ʃaʔ''] word
/e/ does not occur after the nasal stop /n/. /e/ can be long in final syllables and short in non final syllables. Here are some examples:
''traʔw'''ē ́''' [traʔwe]'' middle
''tik'''è'''ʔ [tikeʔ''] aroused
''siy'''ě'''ʔ [sijeʔ]'' dressed up
''tsaʔw'''ě''' [t͜saʔwe]'' good
''nkyas'''e'''ʔ [ŋgjaseʔ]'' it got deflated
n''kyan'''è''' [ŋgjanɛ'']̃ he/she sprayed it
''nkyaʔw'''è''' [ŋgjaʔwe]'' it got split
/i/ occurs in final as well as non-final syllables of roots followed by a /?/. It is slightly restricted in its distribution. Here are some examples:
''p'''i̋'''[pi]'' poult
''p'''ì'''i̋[pi:]'' fair skinned, pale
''ly'''i'''ʔ̋ [li̻ ʔ]'' parrot
''mp'''i'''ʔ̋ [mbiʔ]'' dram
''ki'''i'''ʔ [ki:ʔ]'' fire
The distribution of /u/ is highly restricted. /u/ in monosyllabic words is rare. /u/ can be long in final syllables but is always short in non-final syllables. Here are some examples:
x'''ǔ'''ʔ [ʃuʔ] oldster
ch'''ūú''' [t͜ʃu:] Jesus
s'''ù'''nt'''ū ̋'''[suntu] issue (from Spa. asunto)
b'''ù'''rr'''ū ̋'''[bur̥u] donkey (from Spa. burro)
k'''u'''ʔwǐ [kuʔwi] drunk
s'''u'''ti [suti] his/her father
t'''u'''ʔwa [tuʔwa] his/her mouth
/o/ is restricted as well. It does not occur after the nasal stop /n/ and similarly to /u/, /o/ does not occur after the labiovelars /k<sup>w</sup>/ or /w/. Here are some examples
Ty'''ò''' ̋ [to̻ ] Pedro
k'''ōō''' [ko:] fog
y'''o''' [jo] guy
y'''oo''' [jo:] soil
pìx'''ō''' ̋[piʃo] peso

==Grammar==
===Morphology=== San Marcos Zacatepec is considered a [[head-marking language]] as it is synthetic and analytic. Some functions are the language are mixed; for example, person marking can be signaled through tone contrast and/or [[nasalization]], [[Clitic|encliticization]], or also by a separate word.
Its verbal morphology features a large inventory of [[allomorph]]s of its aspectual morphemes, which makes its verbal paradigms appear extremely irregular.
The sequence classes are “morphological”—some are specialized by part-of-speech, by inflectional category, or loan provenance, while others are open ended and general.<ref name=":0" />
===Syntax=== The basic word order is [[Verb–subject–object|VSO]] but there are other orders present. Here is an example of the Chatino Language VSO: {| class="wikitable" !N-da !nu !xni !ndaha !ska !ha !xtlya !?i !nu !'o |- |con-give |the |dog |lazy |one |tortilla |Spanish |to |the |Coyote |} This would say "The lay dog gave a sweetbread to the coyote".
Some morphemes, such as the marker ''"?in"'' have various functions in the grammar as it is a [[Dative case|dative]] marker. The dative marker introduces human objects, indirect objects, and also marks alienable possession.
Compounding patterns play an important role and word formation. the use of combinations of 'light nouns’ or semantically poor nouns and semantically rich adjectives (or nouns, although very rarely) is very prolific in the language. Villard provides us with an example of such formations: the light noun ''nu'' ‘the one who’, often occurs as a head noun in noun phrases, as in ''nu kīʔyó 'man''' (the one who is male) or ''nu kunāʔán'' 'woman' (the one who is female).
==Vocabulary/Lexis== There are 15 lexical tone classes defined by 15 tone sequences. The sequences pertain to any noncompound stem but have different realizations depending on the number of [[Mora (linguistics)|moras]] in the stem. The sequence classes are “morphological”—some are specialized by part-of-speech, by inflectional category, or loan provenance, while others are open ended and general. Sequence class identity—not tones—determines tonal [[ablaut]] behavior and tonal inflectional classes. The progressive aspect is associated with an M tone which generates composed sequences beyond the original 15 <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.surrey.ac.uk/englishandlanguages/research/smg/events/2014/the_exuberant_tonal_system_of_san_marcos_zacatepec_eastern_chatino.htm|title=The exuberant tonal system of San Marcos Zacatepec Eastern Chatino|website=www.surrey.ac.uk|access-date=2016-05-06}}</ref>
